title: Military history of Germany
text:
The military history of Germany spans the period from ancient times to the present.
Ancient times.
During the <a href="Ancient%20history">ancient</a> and <a href="Early%20Middle%20Ages">early medieval periods</a> the <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic tribes</a> had no <a href="written%20language">written language</a>. What we know about their early military history comes from accounts written in <a href="Latin">Latin</a> and from <a href="archaeology">archaeology</a>. This leaves important gaps. <a href="Germanic%20Wars">Germanic wars</a> against the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a> are fairly well documented from the Roman perspective, such as the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Teutoburg%20Forest">Battle of the Teutoburg Forest</a>. Germanic wars against the early <a href="Celts">Celts</a> remain mysterious because neither side recorded the events.
Germanic tribes are thought to have originated during the <a href="Nordic%20Bronze%20Age">Nordic Bronze Age</a> in northern Germany and southern <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>. The tribes spread south, possibly motivated by the deteriorating climate of that area. They crossed the River <a href="Elbe">Elbe</a>, probably overrunning the territories of the Celtic <a href="Volcae">Volcae</a> in the <a href="Weser">Weser Basin</a>. The Romans recorded one of these early migrations when the <a href="Cimbri">Cimbri</a> and the <a href="Teutons">Teutons</a> tribes threatened the <a href="Roman%20Republic">Republic</a> itself around the late 2nd century BC. In the East, other tribes, such as <a href="Goths">Goths</a>, <a href="Rugii">Rugii</a> and <a href="Vandals">Vandals</a>, settled along the shores of the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a> pushing southward and eventually settling as far away as <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>. The <a href="Angles">Angles</a> and <a href="Saxons">Saxons</a> migrated to <a href="History%20of%20Anglo-Saxon%20England">England</a>. The Germanic peoples often had a fraught relationship with their neighbours, leading to a period of over two millennia of military conflict over various territorial, religious, ideological and economic concerns.
Middle Ages.
The <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> of the German Nation (also referred as the First German Empire) emerged from the eastern part of the <a href="Carolingian%20Empire">Carolingian Empire</a> after its division between the grandchildren of <a href="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Verdun">Treaty of Verdun</a> of 843, and lasted almost a millennium until its <a href="Dissolution%20of%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">dissolution</a> in 1806. It was never a <a href="unitary%20state">unitary state</a>; from the beginning it was made up of many ethnicities and languages and would at its height comprise territories ranging from eastern <a href="France">France</a> to <a href="northern%20Italy">northern Italy</a>. Its unifying characteristic was its Carolingian heritage and strong religious connotations, its claim to "German-ness" the ethnicity of most of its subjects and rulers.
The military history of Germany during the Middle Ages was full of siege warfare and the technological changes that come from fighting that kind of war. From the creation of the First German Empire in 843 until the creation of the <a href="printing%20press">printing press</a> by <a href="Johannes%20Gutenberg">Johannes Gutenberg</a>, the middles ages were fought in similar fashion to those of ancient times. Many changes were made due to the use of siege warfare and new military technologies.
Siege warfare.
During the Middle Ages, siege warfare was the primary way in which war was fought and territory taken through conquest. There were field battles fought, in which they employed a <a href="phalanx">phalanx</a> formation similar to what would have been studied in <a href="Publius%20Flavius%20Vegetius%20Renatus">Vegetius</a>’ "<a href="De%20re%20militari">De re militari</a>". However, the vast majority of battles were fought in defense of or the attempt to take fortifications. The men required to partake in a siege came from different areas of society. There were some nobles, some knights, the kings personal men, as well as the vast majority being peasant farmers conscripted into fighting. Siege warfare in effect was the way in which war was fought in Germany during the Middle Ages; this led to advances in medieval military technology.
Military technology.
With the use of sieges as the primary means of middle age warfare, there were changes in military technology that facilitated fighting this differing kind of warfare. That being said, advances in technology did not mean that old technology became immediately obsolete. One such advance was the <a href="trebuchet">trebuchet</a>, but other smaller advancements were made as well. There were advancements such as new helmets called "<a href="Spangenhelm">Spangenhelm</a>e" as well as some Carolingian developments in weapon production. With the subsequent development in armor, there came advancements in handheld weaponry to deal with these developments. For example, swords became thinner and pointed on the tip in order to penetrate between gaps in plate armor. <a href="Crossbow">Crossbow</a>s as well became more commonly used in the defense of castles during siege warfare. In order to attack castles, the <a href="Springald">Springald</a> was created to launch spears in succession, but was mainly used outside of Germany. Stirrups were developed which was integral in the use of shock combat during the Middle Ages. The creation of <a href="greave">greave</a>s was important in protecting the shins.
The reality of knighthood.
In Germany, <a href="Baronet">Baronet</a>s were known as ("<a href="Ritter">Ritter</a>") or <a href="Knight">Knight</a>s. These were a title of nobility bestowed on people by the local lord. Following this, the title of <a href="Ritter">Ritter</a> was generally passed in a hereditary fashion until the end of the noble line. After which, the title and its holdings would revert to the lord to give out to someone else. Ritter's were considered the elite of the German military as their entire goal was to practice for war. They did this by competing in tournaments to keep themselves practiced. A Ritter would be considered of this lowest nobility but were considered the primary means of defense for many lords. All <a href="knight">knight</a>s were nobility but not all nobles were knights. The nobility were not a military class, but quite contrarily avoided military conflict on the basis of their immense wealth. As well, knights would have been more likely to ravage the countryside in order to get a country to submit to their authority, rather than seek open battle to prove their point.
Fortifications.
Fortifications in Medieval Germany were built similarly to those of the <a href="Roman%20fortifications">Roman style</a>, with the caveat of stone-built <a href="castle">castle</a>s. Forts were generally well constructed and effective against attack. There were several kinds of fortifications such as the moat and bailey, earthworks, hill-forts, Urban forts, <a href="Defensive%20wall">town walls</a>, and fortified residences. <a href="Moat">Moat and bailey</a>, the most common castles before the use of stonework's, proved ineffective against Viking invaders. In Germany, in 1200 there were only 12 towns with walls, and 9 of them were originally <a href="Ancient%20Roman%20defensive%20walls">Roman walls</a>. Later, <a href="Crusades">crusaders</a> built their own types of fortifications called <a href="List%20of%20Crusader%20castles">crusader castles</a>, meant to be used in defense of a strategic objective for <a href="Christendom">Christendom</a>. Mostly, the defense of territory gained in conquest against <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a> in the <a href="Holy%20Land">Holy Land</a>. However, it's possible some could have been built in the <a href="Prussian%20Crusade">Prussian Crusade</a> in the 13th century. This all changed with the influence of gunpowder weapons as used during sieges.
Battle tactics.
The tactics of the Middle Ages varied greatly. A large amount of tactics were still based on Roman ideas. Such as the use of training, regimentation, and the phalanx. Medieval commanders may have been educated or read in <a href="Publius%20Flavius%20Vegetius%20Renatus">Vegetius’</a> "<a href="De%20re%20militari">De Re Militari</a>" which would’ve provided the bases for battle tactics. In historiography, Charles Oman believes that cavalry entirely dominated the battlefield of the Middle Ages, but others contend that the infantry continued to play the most vital role even through the early modern age. One example of tactics and strategy is the use of secrecy in <a href="Henry%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Henry II</a> in 1004 against <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemians</a>, which gave Henry the element of surprise so that he was successful in his campaign. Another strategy, employed primarily by knights, was to ravage the countryside and force people to submit when they run out of supplies. The vast majority of these tactics were learned from Roman times in surviving works.
Ninth century.
In the year 800, <a href="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> is crowned <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Emperor</a> including his dominions in Germany which he gained through military <a href="Saxon%20Wars">conquest of Saxon tribes</a>. Through the ninth Century, after the death of Charlemagne in 814, the empire was split in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Verdun">Treaty of Verdun</a> in 843. This created the kingdoms of <a href="France%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">France</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Germany">Germany</a>, and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy%20%28Holy%20Roman%20Empire%29">Lombardy</a>.
Following the Treaty of Verdun, in 870 there was the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Meerssen">Treaty of Meerssen</a>. This treaty replaced the treaty of Verdun and split the empire again. The <a href="East%20Francia">Kingdom of East Francia</a> (Germany) continued to exist under the conditions of this treaty. However, within 10 years this led to further conflict between German and French Kings.
Tenth century.
In July 907, an army of Germans faced off against <a href="Hungarian%20invasions%20of%20Europe">Hungarians</a> in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Pressburg">Battle of Pressburg</a>. The result was a decisive Hungarian victory in which the Hungarians were able to pillage what is today modern eastern Germany. The following year in 908, the Hungarians scored another victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Eisenach%20%28908%29">Battle of Eisenach</a> and continued to ravage the German countryside and demand tribute from local lords. This trend continued with the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lechfeld">First Battle of Lechfeld</a> in 910 when the <a href="Imperial%20Army%20%28Holy%20Roman%20Empire%29">Imperial Army</a> lost to the Hungarian invaders during the use of a feigned retreat tactic.
From 919–36, the Germanic peoples (<a href="Franks">Franks</a>, <a href="Saxons">Saxons</a>, <a href="Swabia">Swaben</a> and <a href="Bavaria">Bavaria</a>ns) were united under <a href="Henry%20the%20Fowler">Henry the Fowler</a>, then <a href="Duchy%20of%20Saxony">Duke of Saxony</a>, who took the title of King. For the first time, the term Kingdom of the Germans ("Regnum Teutonicorum") was applied to the Frankish kingdom.
The <a href="Treaty%20of%20Bonn">Treaty of Bonn</a> was signed in 921 between <a href="Charles%20the%20Simple">Charles III of France</a> and Henry I of Germany. They established the <a href="Rhine">Rhine River</a> as the border and neutral territory of their kingdoms. The treaty was ultimately a failure and led to tensions and military conflict between the kingdoms.
In 933, <a href="Henry%20the%20Fowler">Henry the Fowler</a> met with an assembly in which they expressed their desire to renew their war with the Magyars (Hungarians). The <a href="Magyars">Magyars</a> attempted to catch the Saxons by surprise, but ultimately failed when they split their army in two. This resulted in Henry destroying both army sections with his superior weapons and training. The name of this conflict was known as the <a href="Battle%20of%20Riade">Battle of Riade</a>.
<a href="Henry%20I%20the%20Fowler">Henry I</a> and his son <a href="Otto%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Otto I</a> inherited their administrative qualities from their <a href="Carolingian%20dynasty">Carolingian</a> ancestors and thus were able to field armies much larger than medieval military historiography believed was capable at that time. The efficiency of military organization in tenth-century Germany was much higher than believable. This can be seen in the number of sieges, which would require extensive logistics, that were conducted during the century. Otto I and his subsequent descendants were tasked with defending the military borders to the east of modern-day Germany. Their enemies were primarily <a href="Slavs">Slavic</a> and roaming <a href="Eurasian%20nomads">Steppe peoples</a>.
In 953-954 <a href="Otto%20the%20Great">Otto the Great</a> was forced to fight his sons <a href="Conrad%20the%20Red">Conrad the Red</a> and Luidolf in a civil war in modern-day Germany. The war was fought over old Roman fortifications such as <a href="Mainz">Mainz</a> and <a href="Regensburg">Regensburg</a>. In the subsequent year, during which the Ottonian kingdom would've been weaker, the Magyars invaded with the objective of besieging cities in search of booty. The number of forts and their organization also pointed to extensive work done by the first kings of Germany during the 10th century during the Middle Ages.
In 955, the Magyars were decisively defeated at the second <a href="battle%20of%20Lechfeld">battle of Lechfeld</a> by <a href="Otto%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Otto the Great</a>, ending the threat from the <a href="Eurasian%20Steppe">Eurasian steppes</a> for four centuries. In 962, partly on the strength of this victory, Otto invaded Italy on his way to Rome and was crowned the first Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by the <a href="pope">pope</a>.
The <a href="War%20of%20the%20Three%20Henries%20%28977%E2%80%93978%29">War of the Three Henries</a> was fought between 977–978. The war was a short lived rebellion by three German princes, all of which were named Henry, against <a href="Emperor%20Otto%20II">Emperor Otto II</a>. The three Henries were, Bishop Henry I of Augsburg, Henry the Wrangler, and duke Henry I the Younger. Shortly after the end of the rebellion of the three Henries, Otto <a href="Franco-German%20war%20of%20978%E2%80%93980">fought a brief war</a> with King <a href="Lothair%20of%20France">Lothair of France</a>, who invaded <a href="Lotharingia">Lotharingia</a> and attacked the imperial city of <a href="Aachen">Aachen</a> with 20,000 men. Otto was forced to flee to <a href="Dortmund">Dortmund</a> where he created an effective response. He then counter-invaded France and <a href="Siege%20of%20Paris%20%28978%29">laid siege to Paris</a> but was forced to withdraw during the winter months. He then turned to defeating the rebellious princes, which he did by besieging <a href="Passau">Passau</a> where the rebels had gathered. Otto took Passau and punished the three princes for their insurrection.
Eleventh century.
Between 1002-1024, <a href="Henry%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Henry II</a> of Germany was able to conscript forces across his entire kingdom for a campaign south of the <a href="Alps">Alps</a> into Italy. As was common in previous centuries, all able-bodied men in the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> were required to defend their home if it was under threat.
Germany during the eleventh century was engulfed in civil war most notably in the 1070s and 1080s. It began during the reign of Henry IV in 1056. During the civil War, <a href="Henry%20IV%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Henry IV</a> found time to siege <a href="Rome">Rome</a> twice in 1081 and 1084. The struggle of the civil war broke German military and political power so that later the kingdom and empire would dissolve into hundreds of autonomous states for some time.
Twelfth century.
By 1155, the <a href="List%20of%20states%20in%20the%20Holy%20Roman%20Empire">German states</a> had descended into disorder. Emperor <a href="Frederick%20I%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Frederick I Barbarossa</a> managed to restore peace through diplomacy and skillfully arranged marriages. He claimed direct imperial control over <a href="Italy">Italy</a> and made several incursions into northern Italy, but was ultimately defeated by the <a href="Lombard%20League">Lombard League</a> at <a href="Battle%20of%20Legnano">Legano</a> in 1176. Despite his defeat, he did manage to receive the imperial coronation from the pope, thus aiding Barbarossa in his efforts to restore the empire to its former glory that it experienced under Otto I. In 1189, Frederick embarked on the <a href="Third%20Crusade">Third Crusade</a>. After a few initial successes against the <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turks</a>, notably at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Iconium%20%281190%29">Battle of Iconium</a>, Frederick died when trying to cross a river. Leaderless, panicked and attacked on all sides, only a tiny fraction of the original forces continued onward.
Towards the end of the twelfth century in 1198, there was the beginning of the <a href="German%20throne%20dispute">German Throne Dispute</a>. <a href="Henry%20VI%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Henry VI</a> died unexpectedly and there was a succession crisis. The direction of the empire was under scrutiny and was altered by the princes of the empire. The result was a conflict that lasted almost 17 years before the son of Henry VI, <a href="Frederick%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Frederick II</a>, was able to regain his title and power as Holy Roman Emperor.
Thirteenth century.
Teutonic Knights
In 1226 <a href="Konrad%20I%20of%20Masovia">Konrad I of Masovia</a> appealed to the <a href="Teutonic%20Knights">Teutonic Knights</a>, a German <a href="Crusades">crusading</a> <a href="Military%20order%20%28society%29">military order</a>, to defend his borders and subdue the pagan <a href="Balts">Baltic</a> <a href="Old%20Prussians">Prussians</a>. The <a href="Prussian%20Crusade">conquest and Christianization</a> of <a href="Prussia%20%28region%29">Prussia</a> was accomplished after more than 50 years, after which the Order ruled it as a sovereign <a href="State%20of%20the%20Teutonic%20Order">Teutonic Order state</a>. Their conflict of interests with the Polish-Lithuanian state lead in 1410 to <a href="Battle%20of%20Grunwald">Battle of Grunwald (Tannenberg)</a> where a Polish-Lithuanian army inflicted a decisive defeat and broke its military power, although the Order withstood the following <a href="Siege%20of%20Marienburg%20%281410%29">Siege of Marienburg</a> and managed to retain most of its territories.
In 1212, <a href="Emperor%20Frederick%20II">Emperor Frederick</a> was forced to fight a civil war to defend his title. He defended his title and owed the <a href="Pope">Pope</a> for acknowledging him and helping him retain his title. For this, Emperor Frederick passed the <a href="Golden%20Bull%20of%20Eger">Golden Bull of Eger</a> in which he made concessions to the church.
In 1244, the <a href="Flemish%20Succession">war of Flemish Succession</a> broke out with two counties, one German and one French, arguing over who was to succeed <a href="Margaret%20II%2C%20Countess%20of%20Flanders">Margaret II, Countess of Flanders</a>. The conflict was between half-brothers, both of whose mother was the aforementioned Margaret, <a href="John%20I%20of%20Avesnes">John I of Avesnes</a> and <a href="Guy%2C%20Count%20of%20Flanders">Guy of Dampierre</a>. The result of the war was John I of Avesnes defeating his mother and half brother with the aid of Count William of Holland.
The <a href="Teltow%20and%20Magdeburg%20Wars">Teltow-Magdeburg Wars</a> were fought in the modern German state of Brandenburg. It was fought between 1239–1245 over the ownership of some eastern German territories. The war was between princes of the Holy Roman Empire. The result was that <a href="Otto%20the%20Pious">Otto the Pious</a> and <a href="John%20I%2C%20Margrave%20of%20Brandenburg">John I of Brandenburg</a> (Brothers who jointly ruled Brandenburg) expanded their holdings in eastern Germany. Following their conquest, the brothers would later go on to help the Teutonic Order defeat a Prussian uprising in the middle of the 1260s.
In 1260, there was a small uprising in the town of <a href="Hamelin">Hamelin</a>. The townsfolk rose up in response to a threat by the <a href="List%20of%20bishops%2C%20prince-bishops%2C%20and%20administrators%20of%20Minden">Bishop of Minden</a>. The Battle took place at the abandoned village of <a href="Sedemuender.">Sedemuender.</a> The result was the total defeat of the townsfolk.
Fourteenth century.
In 1311, "<a href="Reichskrieg">Reichskrieg</a>", (Imperial War) a war between the Holy Roman Empire and the <a href="County%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Count of Württemberg</a> broke out. The Count, <a href="Eberhard%20II%2C%20Count%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Eberhard</a>, was upset that the <a href="Imperial%20ban">imperial Ban</a> was placed on him for the way he handles a court case and crisis around his duties as "<a href="Vogt">Landvogt</a>" (Military Protector).
In 1361, a war between the <a href="Hanseatic%20League">Hanseatic League</a> and the <a href="Danes">Danes</a> broke out. The Hanseatic League won when they conquered <a href="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>. The war lasted nine years and resulted in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Stralsund%20%281370%29">Treaty of Stralsund</a>.
In 1393, the „<a href="Vitalienbr%C3%BCder">Vitalienbrüder</a>,“ or the “<a href="Victual%20Brothers">Victual Brothers</a>” harassed the <a href="Hanseatic%20League">Hansa</a> and other ships on the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic</a> and <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a>s. The pirates were brutal and by 1393 the only way for cargo ships to travel was in convoys. The Hansa built some defensive ships but nothing that could completely wipe of the brothers like they had hoped. It was the master of the Teutonic Knights, <a href="Konrad%20von%20Jungingen">Konrad von Jungingen</a> that besieged and conquered the Vitalienbrüder base at <a href="Gotland">Gotland</a> that finally ended their reign of terror as the remainder of the pirates were forced to move into other seas.
Fifteenth century.
In 1410, the Teutonic Order or (Deutscher Ordensstaat) in German, situated in modern-day Poland, was dealt a defeat by the <a href="Military%20of%20the%20Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish-Lithuanian forces</a> by King <a href="W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw%20II%20Jagie%C5%82%C5%82o">Władysław II Jagiełło</a>. This marked an ending to the power of the German religious state in eastern Europe.
Hussite wars.
The <a href="Hussite%20Wars">Hussite Wars</a>, fought between 1419 and 1434 in <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bohemia">Bohemia</a>, had their origins in a conflict between Catholics and the followers of a religious sect founded by <a href="Jan%20Hus">Jan Hus</a>. The inciting action of the war was the <a href="Defenestrations%20of%20Prague%23First%20Defenestration%20of%20Prague">First Defenestration of Prague</a>, in which the mayor and the town council members of Prague were thrown from the windows of the town building. Emperor <a href="Sigismund%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Sigismund</a>, a firm adherent of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>, obtained the support of <a href="Pope%20Martin%20V">Pope Martin V</a> who issued a <a href="papal%20bull">papal bull</a> in 1420 proclaiming a crusade. In all, four crusades were launched against the heretics, all resulting in defeat for the Catholic troops. The <a href="Hussites">Hussites</a>, capably led by <a href="Jan%20%C5%BDi%C5%BEka">Jan Žižka</a>, employed <a href="Wagenburg">novel tactics</a> to defeat their numerically superior enemies, decisively at <a href="Battle%20of%20Aussig">Aussig</a>. Whenever a crusade would end, the Hussite armies go on <a href="Hussite%20Wars%23Beautiful%20rides">"Beautiful Rides"</a> and would invade the lands where the crusaders were from. One such place was Saxony. After Žižka's death in 1424, the Hussite armies were led by <a href="Prokop%20the%20Great">Prokop the Great</a> to another victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tachov">Battle of Tachov</a> in 1427. The Hussites repeatedly invaded central German lands, though they made no attempt at permanent occupation, and at one point made it all of the way to the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. The Hussite movement was ended in 1434, however, at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lipany">Battle of Lipany</a>.
<a href="Historiography">Historiography</a> tends to believe that the Middle Ages end in 1453 with the emergence of the printing press in Mainz; thus, beginning the early modern age of Germany, and more broadly the early modern European age.
Reformation.
During the <a href="German%20Peasants%27%20War">German Peasants' War</a>, spanning from 1524 to 1525 in the Holy Roman Empire, the <a href="peasant">peasant</a>s rebelled against the <a href="German%20nobility">nobility</a>. The rebellion ultimately failed in the end and Emperor <a href="Charles%20V%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Charles V</a> became much harsher.
Thirty Years War.
From 1618 to 1648 the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a> ravaged Germany, when it became the main theatre of war in the conflict between France and the <a href="Habsburg">Habsburg</a>s for predominance in Europe. Besides being at war with Catholic France, Germany was attacked by the <a href="Lutheran">Lutheran</a> King <a href="Gustavus%20Adolphus%20of%20Sweden">Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden</a>, who won many victories until he was killed at <a href="Battle%20of%20L%C3%BCtzen%20%281632%29">Lützen</a>. The war resulted in large areas of Germany being laid waste, causing general impoverishment and a loss of around a third of its population; it took generations to recover. It ended with the <a href="Peace%20of%20Westphalia">Peace of Westphalia</a>, which stabilized the nation states of Europe.
The imperial general <a href="Prince%20Eugene%20of%20Savoy">Prince Eugene of Savoy</a> faced the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Turks</a> on the battlefield, first coming to prominence during the last major <a href="Battle%20of%20Vienna">Turkish offensive</a> against the Austrian capital of <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> in 1683. By the closing years of the 17th century, he was already famous for securing <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hungary">Hungary</a> from the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and soon rose to the role of principal Austrian commander during the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Spanish%20Succession">War of the Spanish Succession</a>.
18th century.
From 1701–1714 the <a href="War%20of%20the%20Spanish%20Succession">War of the Spanish Succession</a>, Germany fought with the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20England">English</a> and the <a href="Dutch%20Republic">Dutch</a> against the French. During the early part of the war, the French were successful until <a href="Camille%20de%20Tallard">Camille de Tallard</a> was victorious in the <a href="Palatinate%20%28region%29">Palatinate</a>. Later, in 1706, the Germans took back their land with the help of the Dutch and the English. The Austrians pushed the French back in North Italy and the coalition scored several successes in the low countries. At that time, half of the Dutch or the British armies were composed of German mercenaries. The German states that participated in the war were Austria (which contributed the most), Prussia and Hanover.
During the reign of <a href="Frederick%20William%20I%20of%20Prussia">Frederick William I</a> (1713–40), the military power of Prussia was significantly improved. He organized the government around the needs of his army, and produced an efficient, highly disciplined instrument of war. The <a href="Prussian%20Army">Prussian Army</a> was expanded to 80,000 men, about 4% of the total population. Peasants were drafted into the military and trained for duty, but were sent home for ten months out of each year.
Frederick the Great.
<a href="Frederick%20the%20Great">Frederick the Great</a>, king of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Prussia</a> from 1740–86, modernized the <a href="Prussian%20Army">Prussian Army</a>, introduced new tactical and strategical concepts, fought mostly successful wars and doubled the size of Prussia. Frederick had a rationale based on <a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> thought: he launched total wars for limited objectives. The goal was to convince rival kings that it was better to negotiate and make peace than to fight him.
In the <a href="War%20of%20Austrian%20Succession">War of Austrian Succession</a> (1740–48) Empress <a href="Maria%20Theresa%20of%20Austria">Maria Theresa of Austria</a> fought successfully for recognition of her succession to the throne. However, during the subsequent <a href="Silesian%20Wars">Silesian Wars</a> and the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a>, King <a href="Frederick%20the%20Great">Frederick the Great</a> (Frederick II) occupied <a href="Silesia">Silesia</a> and forced Austria to formally cede control in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Hubertusburg">Treaty of Hubertusburg</a> of 1763. Prussia had survived the combined force of its neighbours, each larger than itself, and gained enormously in influence at the cost of the Holy Roman Empire. It became recognised as a great European power, starting a rivalry with Austria for the leadership of the German-speaking lands.
During the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a>, Prussia fought on the side of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Britain</a> against <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russia</a>, <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a>, <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Austria</a>, <a href="Early%20modern%20France">France</a>, and Saxony. Frederick II of Prussia first invaded Saxony and defeated a Saxon army at <a href="Battle%20of%20Lobositz">Lobositz</a>. Frederick would then invade Bohemia, the Prussians besieged <a href="Siege%20of%20Prague">Prague</a>, but they were defeated at <a href="Battle%20of%20Kolin">Kolin</a>. Since Prussia looked vulnerable, the Austrians and French invaded Prussian lands. However, the French were defeated at <a href="Battle%20of%20Rossbach">Rossbach</a> and the Austrians at <a href="Battle%20of%20Leuthen">Leuthen</a>. In 1758, Frederick the Great tried to invade Austria, but he failed. Now, the Russians tried to defeat the Prussians, but the Prussians earned a <a href="pyrrhic%20victory">pyrrhic victory</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Zorndorf">Zorndorf</a>. The Swedes, however, fought the Prussians to a draw at <a href="Battle%20of%20Tornow">Tornow</a>. However, Austria gained a victory against the Prussian main army at <a href="Battle%20of%20Hochkirch">Hochkirch</a>. In 1759, the Prussians lost at <a href="Battle%20of%20Kunersdorf">Kunersdorf</a> to the combined Russians and Austrians. Berlin itself was taken for a few days in 1762, but its army could not be destroyed. However, the great alliance against Prussia broke up when <a href="Elizabeth%20of%20Russia">Elizabeth of Russia</a> died. It was from her death that a pro-Prussian ruler, <a href="Peter%20III%20of%20Russia">Peter III</a> would sue for peace. It was thanks to this "<a href="miracle%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Brandenburg">miracle of the House of Brandenburg</a>" and to the unshakable will of Frederick that Prussia survived.
Napoleonic Wars (1805–15).
The <a href="Napoleonic%20era">Napoleonic era</a> ended the Holy Roman Empire and created new German-speaking states that would eventually form modern Germany. <a href="Napoleon%20I%20of%20France">Napoleon I of France</a> reorganized many of the smaller German-speaking states into the <a href="Confederation%20of%20the%20Rhine">Confederation of the Rhine</a> following the <a href="battle%20of%20Austerlitz">battle of Austerlitz</a> in 1805. Essentially this enlarged the more powerful states of the region by <a href="German%20Mediatisation">absorbing the smaller ones</a>, creating a set of buffer states for France and a source of army conscripts. Neither of the two largest German-speaking states were part of this confederation: the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> and the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> remained outside it.
King <a href="Frederick%20William%20III%20of%20Prussia">Frederick William III of Prussia</a> viewed the Confederation of the Rhine as a threat to Prussian interests and allied against Napoleon. At this time the reputation of the <a href="Royal%20Prussian%20Army%20of%20the%20Napoleonic%20Wars">Royal Prussian Army</a> remained high from the period of the <a href="Seven%20Years%27%20War">Seven Years' War</a>. Unfortunately they retained the tactics of that period and still relied heavily on foreign mercenaries. The lack of military reforms would prove disastrous. Prussian defeats at <a href="Battle%20of%20Jena-Auerstedt">Jena and Auerstedt</a> led to a <a href="Treaties%20of%20Tilsit">humiliating settlement</a> that reduced the size of the country by half.
The <a href="Electorate%20of%20Hanover">Electorate of Hanover</a>, up till the <a href="Convention%20of%20Artlenburg">Convention of Artlenburg</a> ruled in personal union by the English King <a href="George%20III">George III</a>, was incorporated into Prussia. The <a href="King%27s%20German%20Legion">King's German Legion</a> formed in Britain from officers and soldiers of the dissolved Hanoverian army, was the only army of a German state that was continually fighting the Napoleonic army.
A demoralised Prussia brought its distinguished old general <a href="Gebhard%20Leberecht%20von%20Bl%C3%BCcher">Gebhard von Blücher</a> out of retirement and reorganized the army. The reforms of the Prussian military were led by <a href="Gerhard%20von%20Scharnhorst">Scharnhorst</a> and <a href="August%20von%20Gneisenau">Gneisenau</a>, and converted the professional army into one based on national service. They brought in younger leaders, increased the rate of mobilisation and improved their skirmishing and unit tactics. They also organized a centralized <a href="German%20General%20Staff">general staff</a> and a professional officer corps.
Following Napoleon's <a href="Napoleon%27s%20Invasion%20of%20Russia">defeat in Russia</a>, Prussia, Austria and a few other German states saw their chance and joined the anti-French forces in the <a href="Sixth%20Coalition">Sixth Coalition</a>, which won a decisive victory over France at <a href="Battle%20of%20Leipzig">Leipzig</a> in 1813 and forced the abdication of Napoleon. Although declared an outlaw by the <a href="Congress%20of%20Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, Napoleon returned and met a final defeat at the hands of Blücher and <a href="Arthur%20Wellesley%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Wellington">Wellington</a> at <a href="Battle%20of%20Waterloo">Waterloo</a> in 1815.
Uniting Germany (1815–71).
By 1815 there were 39 separate German-speaking states, loosely joined (for free trade purposes) in the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a>, under the leadership of Prussia and Austria. Under the leadership of Chancellor <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>, Prussia united the German states and defeated both Austria and France, 1866 to 1871, allowing the formation of a powerful <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>, which lasted until 1918. Bismarck after 1871 dominated European diplomacy, and set up a complex system of balances that kept the peace. He was replaced in 1890 by the young <a href="Wilhelm%20II%2C%20German%20Emperor">Kaiser Wilhelm II</a>, who built up a powerful Navy to challenge the British, and engaged in reckless diplomacy.
Clausewitz.
<a href="Carl%20von%20Clausewitz">Carl von Clausewitz</a> (1780–1831) was the most important German military theorist; he stressed the moral and political aspects of war. Clausewitz espoused a <a href="romanticism">romantic</a> or <a href="Hegel">Hegel</a>ian conception of warfare, stressing the dialectic of how opposite factors interact, and noting how unexpected new developments unfolding under the "<a href="fog%20of%20war">fog of war</a>" called for rapid decisions by alert commanders. Clausewitz saw history as a complex check on abstractions that did not accord with experience. In opposition to his great rival <a href="Antoine-Henri%20Jomini">Antoine-Henri Jomini</a> he argued war could not be quantified or graphed or reduced to mapwork and graphs. Clausewitz had many aphorisms, of which the most famous is, "War is not merely a political act, but also a political instrument, a continuation of political relations, a carrying out of the same by other means," a working definition of war which has won wide acceptance.
German Empire 1871-1919.
After Prussia under <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a> won a series of wars against Denmark, Austria and France, it united most of the German states into the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>. Its highly professional army set world standards but fought no more wars until 1914.
Wars of Unification.
After a period of constitutional deadlock between crown and parliament in Prussia, a crisis arose in 1863 over the duchies of <a href="Schleswig">Schleswig</a> and <a href="Holstein">Holstein</a>, disputed between <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a> and the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a>. After the Danish annexation of Schleswig, <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>, the new prime Minister of Prussia, made the smaller states of the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a> join Prussia and Austria in the war with Denmark. The <a href="Second%20Schleswig%20War">Second Schleswig War</a> ended with the defeat of the Danes at <a href="Battle%20of%20Dybb%C3%B8l">Dybbøl</a>, and an agreement between Austria and Prussia to jointly administer Schleswig and Holstein.
Bismarck then set about making Prussia the undisputed master of northern Germany, weakening Austria and the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a>. This eventually led to a German civil war, the <a href="Austro-Prussian%20War">Austro-Prussian War</a>, in which in the <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20Langensalza">Battle of Langensalza</a> (the last battle between Germanic states on German soil) Hanover won a victory, but was so weakened by it, that it could offer no resistance to the occupation by Prussia and ceased to be an independent state. The victory of Prussia and its allies at <a href="Battle%20of%20K%C3%B6niggr%C3%A4tz">Königgrätz</a> in July 1866, against Austria and its allies sealed this. The result was the dissolution of the <a href="German%20Confederation">German Confederation</a>, and the creation of the <a href="North%20German%20Confederation">North German Confederation</a> one year later.
Bismarck wanted a war with France to unify the German peoples, and French Emperor <a href="Napoleon%20III">Napoleon III</a>, unaware of his military weakness, provided the <a href="Franco-Prussian%20War">Franco-Prussian War</a> of 1870–71, expecting support from Prussia's recent enemies. Unlike in the war only a few years ago, the Germans turned not against each other, with the first emergence of a strong German national sentiment in the background. Instead, the southern German monarchs of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Bavaria">Bavaria</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Württemberg</a>, and <a href="Grand%20Duchy%20of%20Baden">Baden</a> honoured their secretly negotiated treaties of mutual defence with Berlin, while Austria remained neutral.
The Germans, led by King <a href="William%20I%2C%20German%20Emperor">William I of Prussia</a> and <a href="Helmuth%20von%20Moltke%20the%20Elder">Moltke the Elder</a>, mobilized a mass conscript army of 1.2 million men (300,000 regulars and 900,000 reserves and Landwehr) which faced 492,585 experienced regular French soldiers and "420,000 <a href="Garde%20Mobile">Garde Mobile</a>" under <a href="Napoleon%20III%20of%20France">Napoleon III of France</a>. Within the first month of war the German army encircled big French armies, at <a href="Battle%20of%20Gravelotte">Gravelotte</a>, <a href="Siege%20of%20Metz%20%281870%29">Metz</a>, and <a href="Battle%20of%20Sedan">Sedan</a> and destroyed them. The war culminated with the defeat of the French army during the <a href="Siege%20of%20Paris%20%281870-1871%29">Siege of Paris</a>, and was followed by the proclamation of the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a> in 1871.
Naval race.
The results of these wars was the emergence of a powerful German <a href="nation-state">nation-state</a> and a major shift in the <a href="Balance%20of%20power%20%28international%20relations%29">balance of power</a> on the European continent. The <a href="German%20Army%20%28German%20Empire%29">Imperial German Army</a> now was the most powerful military in Europe. Although Germany now had a parliament, it did not control the military, which was under the direct command of the Kaiser (Emperor). The German economy was rapidly growing, as was German pride and intense nationalism.
After 1890, Germany made a major effort to build up its navy, leading to a naval arms race with Britain. Germany also sought coaling stations because the coal-burning warships had to be refueled frequently, and Britain had a large worldwide network. Efforts to gain <a href="German%20interest%20in%20the%20Caribbean">coaling stations in the Caribbean or west Indies</a> failed. By 1900, the possibility of a conflict between Germany and Britain loomed larger, as Germany built up its own (much smaller) colonial empire, and started a naval race to try and catch up with Britain, the world's dominant naval power.
First World War (1914–18).
The German <a href="Schlieffen%20plan">Schlieffen plan</a> to deal with the Franco-Russian alliance involved delivering a knock-out blow to the French and then turning to deal with the more slowly mobilised Russian army. At the start of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, Germany attacked France through Belgium to avoid French defenses on the French-German border. They were beaten back at the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20the%20Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a>. Three years of stalemated <a href="trench%20warfare">trench warfare</a> on the <a href="Western%20Front%20%28World%20War%20I%29">Western Front</a> produced millions of casualties (with one-third killed). New tactics in 1918 opened up the war, but <a href="German%20spring%20offensive">a series of massive German offensives</a> failed in spring 1918, and Germany went on the defensive as fresh American soldiers arrived at the rate of 10,000 a day. Militarily defeated, stripped of allies, and exhausted on the homefront, Germany signed an armistice in November 1918 that amounted to a surrender.
In the East, however, the war was not confined to trenches. The Russian initial plans for war had called for simultaneous invasions of Austrian <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Galicia%20and%20Lodomeria">Galicia</a> and German <a href="East%20Prussia">East Prussia</a>. Although Russia's initial advance into Galicia was largely successful, it was driven back from East Prussia by the victories of the German generals <a href="Paul%20von%20Hindenburg">Paul von Hindenburg</a> and <a href="Erich%20Ludendorff">Erich Ludendorff</a> at <a href="Battle%20of%20Tannenberg%20%281914%29">Tannenberg</a> and the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20the%20Masurian%20Lakes">Masurian Lakes</a> in August and September 1914. Russia's less-developed economic and military organisation soon proved unequal to the combined might of the German and Austro-Hungarian Empires. In the spring of 1915 the Russians were driven back in Galicia, and in May the Central Powers achieved a remarkable breakthrough on Poland's southern fringes, capturing <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> on 5 August and forcing the Russians to withdraw from all of Poland, known as the "Great Retreat".
The German Fleet spent most of the war bottled up in port; the great <a href="Battle%20of%20Jutland">Battle of Jutland</a> in 1916 showed superior German tactics could not overwhelm the more powerful British fleet. Submarines – the U-boats- were used by the <a href="Imperial%20German%20Navy">Imperial German Navy</a> to sink merchant ships bringing supplies to England. This strategy alienated the United States, which declared war in April 1917. Shipments of food and munitions to Britain and France were increased, as the convoy system largely neutralized the U-boats.
By 1917 the German army had begun employing new <a href="infiltration%20tactics">infiltration tactics</a> in an effort to break the trench warfare deadlock. Units of <a href="Stormtroopers%20%28Imperial%20Germany%29">stormtroopers</a>, were trained and equipped for the new tactics, and were used with devastating effect along the Russian front at Riga then at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Caporetto">Battle of Caporetto</a> in Italy. These formations were then deployed to the Western front to counter the British tank attack at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Cambrai%20%281917%29">Battle of Cambrai</a>.
In March 1918 the German army <a href="German%20spring%20offensive">Spring Offensive</a> began an impressive advance creating a salient in the allied line. The offensive stalled as the British and French fell back and then counterattacked. The Germans did not have the airpower or tanks to secure their battlefield gains. The Allies, invigorated by American manpower, money, and food, counterattacked in late summer and rolled over the depleted German lines, as the German navy rebelled and support for the war on the homefront evaporated.
Weimar Republic and the Third Reich (1918–39).
The <a href="treaty%20of%20Versailles">treaty of Versailles</a> imposed severe restrictions on Germany's military strength. The army was limited to one hundred thousand men with an additional fifteen thousand in the navy. The fleet was to consist of at most six battleships, six cruisers, and twelve destroyers, and the <a href="Washington%20Naval%20Treaty">Washington Naval Treaty</a> established severe tonnage restrictions for German warships. Tanks and heavy artillery were forbidden and the air force was dissolved. A new post-war military (<a href="Reichswehr">Reichswehr</a>) was established in March 1921. General conscription was not allowed. The new <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a> had to follow these restrictions, which worsened its already low public esteem.
General <a href="Hans%20von%20Seeckt">Hans von Seeckt</a> the Army Commander, used the lessons of the First World War and the latest technology to develop advanced tactical doctrines, more efficient organizational structures, and better training that kept the small army ready for expansion. The government secretly trained soldiers in the Soviet Union, but otherwise generally followed the Versailles restrictions while retaining a strong cadre of officers and senior non-coms.
The Nazis came to power in 1933 and began <a href="German%20rearmament">remilitarisation</a>. Heavy military spending quickly restored the <a href="Great%20Depression">depression</a>-ravaged economy, making <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> popular with the people and the military. German armed forces were named the <a href="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> from 1935 to 1945. The Army (<a href="German%20Army%20%28Wehrmacht%29">Heer</a>) was encouraged to experiment with tanks and motorised infantry, using the ideas of <a href="Heinz%20Guderian">Heinz Guderian</a>. The <a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a> restarted naval construction and Hitler established the <a href="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a>, an independent air force.
Threats to use military force were a staple in Nazi foreign policy. They were not actually used except as <a href="German%20involvement%20in%20the%20Spanish%20Civil%20War">German involvement in the Spanish Civil War</a> (1936–39), where the Luftwaffe gained important combat experience.
Second World War (1939–45).
Farrell argues that the historiography of the army in World War Two has been "extremely difficult" because of the stark dichotomy between its superb combat performance and the horrors of its destruction and crimes against civilians and prisoners.
At first Germany's military moves were brilliantly successful, as in the "blitzkrieg" <a href="Invasion%20of%20Poland">invasions of Poland</a> (1939), <a href="Operation%20Weser%C3%BCbung">Norway</a> and <a href="German%20invasion%20of%20Denmark%20%281940%29">Denmark</a> (1940), the <a href="Manstein%20Plan">Low Countries</a> (1940), and above all the stunningly successful <a href="Battle%20of%20France">invasion and quick conquest of France</a> in 1940. Hitler probably wanted peace with Britain in late 1940, but <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, standing alone, was dogged in his defiance. Churchill had major financial, military, and diplomatic help from President <a href="Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, another implacable foe of Hitler. Rising tensions with the Soviet Union eventually led Germany to launch a full-scale invasion of its former ally in June 1941. Hitler's insistence on maintaining high living standards postponed the full mobilization of the national economy until 1942, years after the great rivals Britain, Russia, and the U.S. had fully mobilized.
In September 1939, Germany <a href="Invasion%20of%20Poland">invaded Poland</a> using new tactics that combining the use of tanks, motorised infantry, and air support – known as <a href="Blitzkrieg">Blitzkrieg</a> – caused Polish resistance to collapse within weeks especially once the soviets attacked later that same month from the East.Britain and France declared war but over the winter of 1939–40 there was very little combat in what was called the <a href="Phoney%20War">Phoney War</a>.
In April 1940, in <a href="Operation%20Weser%C3%BCbung">Operation Weserübung</a>, German combined air, land and sea forces invaded and occupied neutral <a href="Denmark%20in%20World%20War%20II">Denmark</a> with little fighting. Then they fought a successful <a href="Norwegian%20Campaign">Norwegian Campaign</a> against the British and Norwegian forces to conquer Norway and to secure access to the North Sea and to <a href="Swedish%20iron%20mining%20during%20World%20War%20II">Swedish iron ore</a>. Sweden remained neutral throughout the war, but Finland fought two wars against the Soviets and became a German ally.
France.
The French plans were largely based on a static defense behind the <a href="Maginot%20Line">Maginot Line</a> – a series of formidable defensive forts along the French-German border. German General <a href="Erich%20von%20Manstein">Erich von Manstein</a> thought on an idea which led eventually to the approval of a "Sichelschnitt" ('Sickle Cut') plan to the conquest of France. On 10 May 1940 the Germans bypassed the <a href="Maginot%20Line">Maginot Line</a> by launching another "Blitzkrieg" through neutral Belgium, Luxemburg and the Netherlands, drawing the Allied forces out. The main thrust of the <a href="Battle%20of%20France">Battle of France</a> attack however was through the <a href="Ardennes">Ardennes</a> which were to that time believed impenetrable to tanks. The <a href="British%20Expeditionary%20Force%20%28World%20War%20II%29">British Expeditionary Force</a> and other allied units were driven back to the coast at <a href="Battle%20of%20Dunkirk">Dunkirk</a>, but managed to escape with most of their troops when Germany made a mistaken decision not to attack with tanks. In June 1940, with French troops encircled and cut off in the north, France asked for an armistice that allowed Germany to control most of the French coast and left <a href="Vichy%20France">Vichy France</a> under German domination.
Battle of Britain.
Hitler at least wanted to threaten an <a href="Operation%20Sea%20Lion">invasion of Britain</a>, perhaps to force a peace, so an armada of small boats and a large combat force was assembled in northern France. The <a href="Battle%20of%20Britain">Battle of Britain</a> was of basic strategic significance, for Berlin believed that it could defeat Britain only by physical invasion by the Army, codenamed <a href="Operation%20Sea%20Lion">Operation Sea Lion</a>. The <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> had rescued its soldiers at <a href="Dunkirk%20evacuation">Dunkirk</a> but lost most of its equipment and weapons, and was no match for the fully equipped German army. The invasion could succeed only if the Luftwaffe could guarantee the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> would not be able to attack the landing force. To do so, the Royal Air Force had to be defeated.
The Battle took place August to September 1940. The Luftwaffe used 1300 medium bombers guarded by 900 fighters; they made 1500 sorties a day from bases in France, Belgium and Norway. The <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> (RAF) had 650 fighters, with more being produced every day. Thanks to radar technology, the British knew where the Germans were, and could concentrate their counterattacks. The Germans used their strategic bombing doctrine to focus on RAF airfields and radar stations. After the <a href="RAF%20Bomber%20Command">RAF bomber forces</a> (quite separate from the <a href="RAF%20Fighter%20Command">fighter forces</a>) <a href="Bombing%20of%20Berlin%20in%20World%20War%20II">attacked Berlin</a> and other cities (a war crime), Hitler swore revenge and diverted the Luftwaffe to <a href="The%20Blitz">attacks on London</a> (a war crime). The success the Luftwaffe was having in rapidly wearing down the RAF was squandered, as the civilians being hit were far less critical than the airfields and radar stations that were now ignored. The last German daylight raid was September 30; the Luftwaffe was taking unacceptable losses and broke off the attacks; occasional air raids hit London and other cities from time to time before May 1941, killing over 42,000 civilians. The Luftwaffe lost 1733 planes, the British, 915. The British showed more determination, better radar, and better ground control, while the Germans violated their own doctrine with wasted attacks on London.
The British surprised the Germans with their high quality aircraft; flying close to home bases where they could refuel, and using radar as part of an integrated air defense system, they had a significant advantage over German aircraft operating at long ranges. The <a href="Hawker%20Hurricane">Hawker Hurricane</a> fighter played a vital role for the RAF in winning the Battle of Britain in the summer of 1940. A fast, heavily armed monoplane that went into service in 1937, the Hurricane was effective against both German fighters and bombers and accounted for 70–75% of German losses during the battle of Britain. The Germans immediately pulled out their <a href="Junkers%20Ju%2087">Stukas</a>, which were no match against the Hurricanes and <a href="Supermarine%20Spitfire">Supermarine Spitfire</a>s. The Battle of Britain showed the world that Hitler's vaunted war machine could be defeated.
Barley (2004) identifies numerous failures by the <a href="Oberkommando%20der%20Wehrmacht">German high command</a>. Hitler was indecisive, failing to identify a political goal that would define the military mission. Luftwaffe planning was muddled, and overlooked the important lessons learned in Spain. The operation was poorly supported by German intelligence. Germany failed to adhere to two key principles of war: know your enemy and yourself, and select and maintain your aim.
Balkans.
To support their weakened Italian allies who had started several invasions, in early 1941 Germany deployed troops in <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> and <a href="North%20African%20Campaign">North Africa</a>. In the Balkans it was a matter of guerrilla war which was extremely violent on all sides. These deployments disrupted Berlin's timetable, and delayed the invasion of the Soviet Union.
Operation Barbarossa.
Hitler made the fateful decision to invade Russia in early 1941, but was delayed by the need to take control of the Balkans. Europe was not big enough for both Hitler and Stalin, and Hitler realized the sooner he moved the less risk of American involvement. Stalin thought he had a long-term partnership and rejected information coming from all directions that Germany was about to invade in June 1941. As a result, the Russians were poorly prepared and suffered huge losses, being pushed back to Moscow by December before holding the line. Hitler imagined that the Soviet Union was a hollow shell that would easily collapse, like France. He therefore had not prepared for a long war, and did not have sufficient winter clothing and gear for his soldiers. Weinberg (1994) argues that decisions concerning the invasion of the Soviet Union in June 1941 must be understood in the broader context of Hitler's ideological motivations and long-term goals. Although Hitler had decided to invade the Soviet Union as early as 1940, German resources never reflected this; armaments production, tank and aircraft construction, and logistical preparations focused on the West. Diplomatic activity was similarly skewed; Hitler granted Stalin any territory he wanted (such as Lithuania), knowing they would soon be at war and Germany would reclaim it anyway. Hitler, blinded by his racist prejudices against Slavs, believed the Eastern campaign would be quick and easy. His real strategic concern was Great Britain and the United States, and his planning consistently demonstrated this.
The Balkan operation had caused a delay, and about six weeks later than planned, on 22 June 1941, Germany reneged on its <a href="non-aggression%20pact">non-aggression pact</a> with the Soviet Union and launched <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>. The German army and its allies made enormous territorial gains in the first months of the war, reaching the outskirts of Moscow when winter set in. Expecting another "Blitzkrieg" victory, the Germans had not properly prepared for warfare in winter and over long distances.
High Point and Collapse.
The years 1941/1942 saw the high point for the German army which controlled an area from <a href="France">France</a> to deep into <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, and from <a href="Norway">Norway</a> to western <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>. Consequently, it also proved to be the turning point. The harsh Russian winters and long supply lines worked in Russia's favour and German armies were decisively defeated in early 1943 at <a href="Battle%20of%20Stalingrad">Stalingrad</a> and later in the gigantic tank battle at <a href="Battle%20of%20Kursk">Kursk</a>. British and American forces cut off reinforcements to North Africa, defeated Field Marshal <a href="Erwin%20Rommel">Erwin Rommel</a>, and captured the German and Italian forces there.
Hitler was technologically oriented and promoted a series of new secret weapons, such as the jet plane, the jet-powered missile (<a href="V-1%20flying%20bomb">V-1</a>), the rocket-powered missile (<a href="V-2%20rocket">V-2</a>), and vastly improved submarines. However he failed to support development of nuclear weapons or proximity fuses, and trailed the Allies in radar. He failed to take advantage of the German lead in jet planes.
In early 1943 the Soviet victory at Stalingrad marked the beginning of the end, as Germany was unable to cope with the superior manpower and industrial resources of the Allies. <a href="North%20African%20campaign">North Africa</a>, <a href="Allied%20invasion%20of%20Sicily">Sicily</a>, and <a href="Allied%20invasion%20of%20Italy">southern Italy</a> fell in 1943. Hitler rescued <a href="Benito%20Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> from prison. Mussolini set up a new "<a href="Italian%20Social%20Republic">Salo Republic</a>" but he was a mere puppet, as German forces blocked the Allies from the industrial northern third of Italy. The Russians pushed forward relentlessly in the East, while the Allies in the west launched a major bombing campaign in 1944–45 that destroyed all major and many smaller German cities, ruined transportation, and signaled to Germans how hopeless their cause was.
The Allies <a href="Normandy%20landings">invaded France</a> in June 1944 as the Russians launched another attack on the east. Both attacks were successful and by the end of 1944, the end was in sight. Hitler did launch a surprise attack at the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Bulge">Bulge</a> in December 1944; it was his last major initiative and it failed, as Allied armor rolled into Germany. Disregarding his generals, Hitler rejected withdrawals and retreats, counting more and more on nonexistent armies. Hitler committed suicide in his underground bunker in Berlin as his last soldiers were overwhelmed by Soviet armies in <a href="Battle%20of%20Berlin">intensely bloody battles</a> overhead.
Cold War (1945–89).
Among the legacies of the Nazi era were the <a href="Nuremberg%20Trials">Nuremberg Trials</a> of 1945–1949. These established the concept of <a href="war%20crime">war crime</a>s in international law and created the precedent for trying future war criminals.
West Germany.
In 1949, <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a> (Federal Republic of Germany) was formed from the French, British and American zones, while the Soviet zone formed <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a> (German Democratic Republic). The western territory of Germany fell under the protection of the <a href="NATO">NATO</a> alliance in the west, while the eastern state joined the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>. Each state possessed its own military force, with eastern Germany formed along the Soviet model and federal Germany adopting a more 'western' organisation. The allied zones of Berlin became de facto part of the Federal Republic of Germany despite the city's location deep in the German Democratic Republic. That resulted in a special situation for <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, i.e. the draft was not in effect in <a href="West%20Berlin">West Berlin</a>. This condition continued until 1990 when the two states were <a href="German%20reunification">reunited</a>.
The <a href="Bundeswehr">Bundeswehr</a> was established in 1955 in West Germany. In 1956, conscription for all men between 18 and 45 in years was introduced after heavy discussions about re-militarising Germany. A significant exception came from the <a href="conscientious%20objector">conscientious objector</a> clause in the West German constitution: West Germany was the first country to grant alternative service to all men who objected to military service on ethical grounds, regardless of religious affiliation. This was named "Zivildienst" roughly translated as "civil services".
<a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a> analysts considered Germany the most likely location for the outbreak of a possible <a href="World%20War%20III">Third World War</a>. Tensions ran high during 1948 when the Soviet Union and "Sowjetische Besatzungszone" (Soviet Occupied Territories) closed all roads bringing supplies to West Berlin. The <a href="Berlin%20Blockade%23The%20start%20of%20the%20Berlin%20Airlift">Berlin Airlift</a> sustained the population and avoided a new war. Construction of the <a href="Berlin%20Wall">Berlin Wall</a> was in 1961.
During the Cold War the Bundeswehr had a strength of 495,000 military and 170,000 civilian personnel. The army consisted of three corps with 12 divisions, most of them armed with tanks and APCs. The air force owned major numbers of tactical combat aircraft and took part in <a href="Integrated%20NATO%20Air%20Defense%20System">NATO's integrated air defence (NATINADS)</a>. The navy was tasked to defend the "Baltic Approaches" and to contain the <a href="Soviet%20Navy">Soviet Navy</a>'s <a href="Baltic%20Fleet">Baltic Fleet</a>.
The United States played a dominant role in NATO, and had its own forces stationed in Germany as well. Cooperation between the two militaries was extensive and cordial. Joint exercises and close collaboration allowed the German and American armies to learn from each other regarding strategy, tactics and technology. However, there were failures when it came to a joint venture in tank design in the 1960s, and the lack of cooperation in developing infantry fighting vehicles.
East Germany.
In East Germany, the Nationale Volksarmee (<a href="National%20People%27s%20Army">National People's Army</a>) or NVA was founded on 1 March 1956. It grew steadily by gradual stages from the police force in the Soviet occupation zone in 1945 until the consolidation in the defense establishment in the 1970s. It was a professional volunteer army until 1962, when conscription was introduced. In 1987 at the peak of its power, the NVA numbered 175,300 troops. Approximately 50% of this number were career soldiers, while the remaining half were short-term conscripts. The armed forces were controlled by the <a href="National%20Defense%20Council%20of%20East%20Germany">National Defense Council</a>, except that the mobile forces were under the <a href="Warsaw%20Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> Unified Command. Political control of the armed forces was through close integration with the SED (Communist Party), which vetted all the officers. Popular support for the military establishment was bolstered by military training provided by the school system and through the growing militarization of society. From a Leninist perspective, the NVA stood as a symbol of Soviet-East German solidarity and became the model Communist institution—ideological, hierarchical, and disciplined. The NVA synthesized Communist and Germanic symbolism, naming its officers' academy after <a href="Karl%20Marx">Karl Marx</a>'s coauthor <a href="Friedrich%20Engels">Friedrich Engels</a>, and its highest medal after Prussian General <a href="Gerhard%20von%20Scharnhorst">Gerhard von Scharnhorst</a>.
At the critical moment in its history in November 1989, the NVA refused to battle the demonstrators protesting the Communist regime. <a href="Mikhail%20Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> refused to let Soviet troops become engaged, and so not just the leadership but the entire Communist system in East Germany collapsed, and the country was soon absorbed by West Germany.
Post-Cold War to present-day.
German reunification.
In the <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Final%20Settlement%20with%20Respect%20to%20Germany">Treaty on the Final Settlement with Respect to Germany</a> (1990), Germany agreed to reduce the strength of its combined armed forces to no more than 370,000 men. After reunification, the <a href="Bundeswehr">Bundeswehr</a> absorbed parts of the Nationale Volksarmee of the GDR, which was being dissolved. In 1999, the <a href="Kosovo%20War">NATO war on Yugoslavia in Kosovo</a> was the first offensive conflict in which the German military actively took part since the Second World War. In 2000, the <a href="European%20Court%20of%20Justice">European Court of Justice</a> opened up the previously all-male (besides medical divisions and the music corps) Bundeswehr to women. Since the early 1990s, the Bundeswehr became more engaged in international <a href="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping missions</a> in and around the <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">former Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="Somalia">Somalia</a>, <a href="Djibouti">Djibouti</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>, and <a href="Sudan">Sudan</a>.
War on terrorism.
As part of <a href="Operation%20Enduring%20Freedom">Operation Enduring Freedom</a> as a response to those attacks, Germany deployed approximately 2,250 troops including <a href="Kommando%20Spezialkr%C3%A4fte">KSK</a> special forces, naval vessels and NBC cleanup teams to <a href="War%20in%20Afghanistan%20%282001%E2%80%932021%29">Afghanistan</a>. German forces have contributed to <a href="International%20Security%20Assistance%20Force">ISAF</a>, the NATO force in Afghanistan, and a <a href="Provincial%20Reconstruction%20Team">Provincial Reconstruction Team</a>. German army <a href="Sikorsky%20CH-53%20Sea%20Stallion">CH-53</a> helicopters have deployed to Afghanistan, one crashed in December 2002 in <a href="Kabul">Kabul</a>, killing seven German soldiers. Eleven other German soldiers have been killed: four in two different ordnance-defusing accidents, one in a vehicle accident, five in two separate suicide bombings, and one in landmine explosion. German forces were in the more secure north of the country and Germany, along with some other larger European countries (with the exception of the UK, Estonia, the Netherlands and Norway), were criticised for not taking part in the more intensive <a href="Coalition%20combat%20operations%20in%20Afghanistan%20in%202006">combat operations</a> in southern Afghanistan in 2006.
Reorientation of the Bundeswehr.
A major event for the German military was the suspension of the compulsory conscription for men in 2011. In 2011/12, a major reform of the Bundeswehr was announced, further limiting the number of military bases and soldiers. As of December 2012, the number of active military personnel in the Bundeswehr was down to 191,818, corresponding to a ratio of 2.3 active soldiers per 1,000 inhabitants. Military expenditure in Germany was at €31.55 billion in 2011, corresponding to 1.2% of GDP. Both the number of active soldiers and the military expenditure placed Germany below comparable countries of the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> such as France and the United Kingdom. While this was already true in absolute terms, the difference was even more pronounced when taking into account Germany's larger population and economy. Thus, Germany appears less prepared to pay for the military and to attach less importance to defense than comparable countries. This stance often draws criticism from Germany's military allies, especially the United States.
In May 2016, the German government announced it would spend <a href="Euro">€</a>130 billion on new equipment by 2030 and add nearly 7,000 soldiers by 2023 in the first German military expansion since the end of the Cold War. In February 2017, the German government announced another expansion, which would increase the number of its professional soldiers by 20,000 by 2024.
Reduction of foreign armed forces.
Whereas Soviet/Russian soldiers fully withdrew from reunified Germany after the Cold War, the United States have only reduced their forces, maintaining a contingent of 47,761 troops as of 2012. The <a href="British%20Armed%20Forces">British Armed Forces</a> will discontinue their <a href="British%20Forces%20Germany">deployment in Germany</a> by 2020. French soldiers will continue to be deployed on German soil as a part of the <a href="Franco-German%20Brigade">Franco-German Brigade</a>.
